message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-blocker used for BPH, which has helped improve symptoms. Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that can also be used for BPH, and would be the most appropriate addition to terazosin in this case. Oxybutynin is used for urge incontinence, not BPH. Tadalafil is used for erectile dysfunction, not BPH. Tamsulosin is also an alpha-blocker used for BPH, but addition of a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor would be more appropriate in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin, the current medication, is an alpha-blocker that helps with BPH symptoms. Finasteride, an inhibitor of 5-alpha-reductase, is also used to treat BPH by reducing prostate size. Oxybutynin and tadalafil are used for overactive bladder and erectile dysfunction, respectively, which are not the primary concerns in this case. Tamsulosin, another alpha-blocker, may be used in addition to terazosin, but finasteride is a better option if a single additional medication is needed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and terazosin helps improve his symptoms. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that can decrease the size of the prostate and relieve symptoms of BPH. Oxybutynin is used for overactive bladder, which is not a concern in this case. Tadalafil is used for erectile dysfunction and is not indicated. Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 blocker that can also relieve symptoms of BPH, but since terazosin is already being used and improving the patient's symptoms, it may not be necessary to switch to tamsulosin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and the digital rectal exam confirms an enlarged prostate. Terazosin, which he has been taking, is an alpha-1 blocker used to relieve BPH symptoms. Among the options, finasteride is a medication that can help shrink the prostate and improve symptoms of BPH. Oxybutynin is used to treat urinary incontinence, which is not a prominent symptom of this patient. Tadalafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction and does not address urinary symptoms. Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 blocker like Terazosin, but switching to another alpha-1 blocker may not be as effective as adding Finasteride.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), with a prostate size of 50 grams without fluctuance or tenderness. Tamsulosin is commonly used to treat BPH, but in this case, the patient has a post-void residual volume of 120 mL, which is a contraindication for alpha blockers like tamsulosin. Finasteride inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which slows the growth of the prostate and is an appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient. Oxybutynin is used to treat urinary incontinence, which is not a present symptom. Tadalafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction and is not indicated for BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and terazosin can improve symptoms of BPH by relaxing smooth muscles. Finasteride, a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, can shrink the prostate and improve urinary flow. Oxybutynin is used for urinary incontinence and tadalafil is used for erectile dysfunction. Tamsulosin is also used for BPH but is less effective than finasteride for reducing prostate size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Finasteride inhibits the production of dihydrotestosterone, a hormone that contributes to prostate growth, making it an appropriate medication for managing BPH. Oxybutynin is used to treat overactive bladder, which is not the primary issue for this patient. Tadalafil can help with erectile dysfunction but is not the primary therapy for BPH. Tamsulosin also helps with BPH, but in this patient's case, finasteride is the more appropriate choice due to the size of the prostate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Terazosin is an alpha-adrenergic blocker that helps to relieve the urinary symptoms. Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that can delay the progression of BPH and is indicated in patients with prostate enlargement greater than 30 grams. Oxybutynin is used for bladder overactivity, which is not indicated in this patient’s case. Tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. Tamsulosin is also an alpha-adrenergic blocker, but it is not indicated in patients with prostate enlargement greater than 30 grams. Therefore, the most appropriate additional pharmacotherapy at this time is finasteride.

Oxybutynin is used to treat overactive bladder, which is not the main concern in this case. Tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor used for erectile dysfunction, which is also not the main concern in this case. Tamsulosin is another alpha-blocker used for BPH, but it does not reduce prostate size.

Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that can also be used to treat BPH by reducing prostate size. Oxybutynin is used to treat overactive bladder, which is not indicated in this case. Tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor used for erectile dysfunction, which is not indicated in this case.
